/lit/ is for the discussion of literature, specifically books (fiction & non-fiction), short stories, poetry, creative writing, etc. If you want to discuss history, religion, or the humanities, go to /his/. If you want to discuss politics, go to /pol/. Philosophical discussion can go on either /lit/ or /his/, but those discussions of philosophy that take place on /lit/ should be based around specific philosophical works to which posters can refer.

Check the wiki, the catalog, and the archive before asking for advice or recommendations, and please refrain from starting new threads for questions that can be answered by a search engine.

/lit/ is a slow board! Please take the time to read what others have written, and try to make thoughtful, well-written posts of your own. Bump replies are not necessary.

>>21273081
>What are the best ways to learn a language? Post resources and opinions.
Primates have a part of their brain that is used for ultra-fast learning. "Monkey see monkey do" comes from this: apes can see other apes do something, and translate the visual information into proprioception. That is, if they see it done, they can do it. Humans, however, use this part of the brain for language processing. This allows for us to use language (if I tell you something, you can repeat it flawlessly, just like an ape could do something if it sees me do something), but it means that we aren't all that good at just seeing something. You need to practice. For languages, there's four things: reading, writing, speaking, listening. Reading is really fucking easy.

Go download Anki, and start adding flashcards. Study the grammar, and get a set of flashcards of the top 500 words. Add them, do them. Add words as you go.

>>21274423
NTA but Latin is archetypal of every IE language while being very regular. Once you "get" Latin, as in how the grammar works, it's just a matter of plugging in new stuff. Greek is "just Latin", but with articles, and it uses preposition plus dative constructions and has a third number, for example. This is a grand simplification, but you'll never have to do the "hurrr durr what is grammatical number durrrrrrr" bit again.

A word that rose to honor at the time of the Renaissance, and that summarized in advance the whole program of modern civilization is 'humanism'. Men were indeed concerned to reduce everything to purely human proportions, to eliminate every principle of a higher order, and, one might say, symbolically to turn away from the heavens under pretext of conquering the earth; the Greeks, whose example they claimed to follow, had never gone as far in this direction, even at the time of their greatest intellectual decadence, and with them utilitarian considerations had at least never claimed the first place, as they were very soon to do with the moderns. Humanism was form of what has subsequently become contemporary secularism; and, owing to its desire to reduce everything to the measure of man as an end in himself, modern civilization has sunk stage by stage until it has reached the level of the lowest elements in man and aims at little more than satisfying the needs inherent in the material side of his nature, an aim that is in any case quite illusory since it constantly creates more artificial needs than it can satisfy.

last_replies.com:
>>21269275
>It doesn't need to be in the book
A book doesn't need to exist. A writer decides what he's going for and what he likes. The reader may or may not appreciate what the writer is trying to do. There is room for all sorts.

>furthering anything resembling a story
Ah yes, ticking off plot points is the totality of a story and literature is only plot points. In reality it is an aesthetic experience. The writer is guiding the reader's imagination to create it. And the writer decides what is furthering the story and not, because it is theirs. There are feelings and realisations and recollections that are beyond what simply understanding written information conventionally will give. Little things like that are most important because it is a different mode to simply conveying information in a narrow, low imagination way.

And I say all this while preferring minimalism. Because wading through bloat and pedantry stunts this process. And is often the other side of the coin of this failure of imagination. I dislike the writing in this but as I said, there is room for all sorts.

You say this, however when there are millions of things to choose from, there's no direction to show you why you should choose any one thing over another. The Christian worldview provides a kind of beginning, which is less of a single path than a superstructure that orders other paths into a workable hierarchy. You can take a leap of faith and fixate on one path to spontaneously create meaning which is the Kierkegaardian route. Or you can go the Nietzschean route and make your own path without religious faith, but then you have to accept with Dionysian pessimism the inherent tragedy of life. People generally are not strong enough to cope with the intense suffering that any path requries without some kind of narrative. The Christian narrative is a pragmatic choice because its success is not dependent on the fulfilment of material conditions, so it gives continual meaning despite the randomness and contingency of the material world.

I want to talk about theatre. How can it be overhauled and made relevant, vital to a mod aud like it was with the greeks or during the renaissance?

I started meditating because of insomnia and i wanted to be free of obsessive thoughts. I downloaded WakingUp app, i did it every day until free period ended. Then i turned into non-guided meditation, but because i never read books about it, my method was similiar to WakingUp one and inspired by anon posts too - i breathe in and out with closed eyes, sometimes i count breaths but then i try to stop counting, and turn to "passive observer" of breaths - keeping concentration on breath, yet letting it flow automatically, without controlling it. Success of my method is various, sometimes i can do 10 or 15 minutes no problem, but often when i do 20minutes i get restless, my mind wanders and it starts to become uncomfortable. Anyway my method is probably most similiar to thing commonly called as "mindfullness" method - pleb shit.
Recently i read few chapters of pic related (McMindfullness) where guy writes "mindfullness" trend is created by bloodthirsty capitalists to help wagies cope. I thought this guy has a point. For example today i listened to guided mindfullness meditation on DailyYoga app, and not only it was strikingly similiar to WakingUp one it also had mantra like "next time you will be in stressfull situation you will be calm and collected". Not only i felt dejavu (like i heard the same exact mantra before) but it sounds like clear cope for me - like stress is inevitable part of capitalism and your only choice is to "deal with it". I also use "yoga nidra" guided meditation videos to help me sleep. I thought its pretty helpful for that but i also felt this vague feeling of sadness toward end of this recording.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8mM5Oks8yZc
She says something like "imagine you are at the beautiful lake and you watch this big setting sun and you feel warm and calmness, and air is just like after the thunder, fresh and joyful" and i had this image of office drones in their 4 walls who never see things like that, and they need to be hushed and told bedtime stories like children or else they risk getting nervous breakdown. In summary - by my own thoughts and reading of pic related i realized mindfullness meditation is kinda mid fr.

Calf raises require a shit ton of reps to do anything. This is just because of the muscle itself. In this way, the best exercise for your calves is running / walking. threads.com: Does anyone get the feeling when reading Melville that he is totally separate from the literary world? I can't find any influences in his writing, and I feel as though it is not just another style or school under X curriculum. There is something that really sets it apart - by which I don't just mean how good it is etc. I mean I really feel like I am not reading the same product of a global literary umbrella as I do when I read almost anything else.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21269973
>>21270432

I just started reading Shakespeare (for fun) after reading Moby Dick, I decided 18th & 19th century lit is the place to be, so it's best to study the major influences of those writers. Only after a few plays and some time investment did it start to flow. If anything I'd say his plays are all over the place in terms of content and mood, you sort have to know what you're in for and make sure it matches what you want.

The Tempest - a lighter semi-comedy, prepare to have your expectations subverted
Othello - Iago is the villian you love to hate, prepare for tragedy
Romeo & Juliet - unexpectedly moving, some really beautiful prose
The Merchant of Venice - a feel good comedy, that's actually quite subversive and will fuck with you
Much Ado About Nothing - a good comedy, great banter, hidden message
A Midsummer Night's Dream - full of fairies and seems likes it for fags, actually funny, hidden message (notice a trend)

If anything, I'm starting to think Shakespeare's comedies are more impactful than his tragedies, he's both laughing with us and laughing at us, in a profound corpus-wide statement on the paradoxical beauty of human frailty.

If I were you I'd try mixing them up: comedy-tragedy-comedy-tragedy-history. Be prepared to read a play at least until Act 3, when you've been unintentionally "hooked" and you realize yet again there's actually something to The Bard.

The core of Berserk is fate. And one man fighting fate really hard, and many others being consumed by one man’s great fate. All the fucked up stuff is kind of irrelevant to me, Miura did create a fascinating world that would be unbearable without Guts and his gang. But Berserk is pure fantasy so while I think there are some interesting themes I don’t think it offers much to really think about outside of sectioned off ideas.

This is the problem I have with a lot of Japanese fiction, they romanticize the fuck out of certain ideas and it may be fun, it may be easy to envelope yourselves in it. But things like a superhuman fighting against fate, and this idealized form of friendship that transcends all boundaries is silly. It’s complete fantasy. I think this is part of the reason why japs seem to always have a hard time creating an ending to the stuff they write too.

Best is to read books by or about the sort of person you have in mind, and get a feel for how they think and behave.

A few typical non-fiction titles:

— The Voyage of the Beagle
English gentleman with a sort of scientific bent goes on a sea trip.

— Goodbye To All That
English [well, sort of] gentleman dislikes public school and then dislikes WWI.

— The Ascent Of Everest
English gentlemen climb mountain.

— The Lonely Sea and the Sky
English gentleman sails round the world.

— A Time Of Gifts

Man has primordial spiritual origin. Materialism bad. Caste system good.
Man and woman are opposite principles.
In his idealized spirituality is man viewed as equal to "supernatural", affecting it just as much as being affected by it (magic).
There are two kinds of spirituality:
Northern light: symbolized by Sun, man, concept of divine leader, heroism, magic
Southern light: Moon, woman, priest class, submission.
He believes that royality is defined by its spirituality and royality based on "blood" is materialistic degradation. Holy Roman Empire is most close to his ideal in Western world.
He hated protestants, he liked some forms of catholicism such as templars.
Civilizations have life cycles. Created from primordial origin, and then degrading to lower forms. There are 4 phases in life of civilization
1. Golden age: Northern spirituality, Sun, divine royality in the lead of civs, Rome, Egypt, India at its peak, orientation to heaven
2. Silver age: Southern spirituality: priest caste as leaders, submissive spirituality, orientation to soil, Christianity, Cult of Isis, Aphroditian cult
3. Bronze age: degenerated forms of N.light and S.light fighting for dominance. Rise of materialism, rise of merchant caste, late Euro monarchies
4. Iron/Dark age: democracy, socialism, death of caste system, death of tradition, technocracy, government of mass.
Contrary to popular belief, he despised most modern forms of nationalism (deprived of their spiritual roots). He also despised biological racism based on Darwin´s evolutionarism. If he speaks about racism he means "race of soul" and "race of spirit". Jews (as a culture) degenerated Roman spirituality through Christianity and later degenerated western world as a "merchant caste".

If you are alluding to Dostoevsky’s worst novels, then, indeed, I dislike intensely The Brothers Karamazov and the ghastly Crime and Punishment rigamarole. No, I do not object to soul-searching and self-revelation, but in those books the soul, and the sins, and the sentimentality, and the journalese, hardly warrant the tedious and muddled search. Dostoyevsky’s lack of taste, his monotonous dealings with persons suffering with pre-Freudian complexes, the way he has of wallowing in the tragic misadventures of human dignity – all this is difficult to admire. I do not like this trick his characters have of ”sinning their way to Jesus” or, as a Russian author, Ivan Bunin, put it more bluntly, ”spilling Jesus all over the place."Crime and Punishment’s plot did not seem as incredibly banal in 1866 when the book was written as it does now when noble prostitutes are apt to be received a little cynically by experienced readers. Dostoyevsky never really got over the influence which the European mystery novel and the sentimental novel made upon him. The sentimental influence implied that kind of conflict he liked—placing virtuous people in pathetic situations and then extracting from these situations the last ounce of pathos. Non-Russian readers do not realize two things: that not all Russians love Dostoevsky as much as Americans do, and that most of those Russians who do, venerate him as a mystic and not as an artist. He was a prophet, a claptrap journalist and a slapdash comedian. I admit that some of his scenes, some of his tremendous farcical rows are extraordinarily amusing. But his sensitive murderers and soulful prostitutes are not to be endured for one moment—by this reader anyway. Dostoyevsky seems to have been chosen by the destiny of Russian letters to become Russia’s greatest playwright, but he took the wrong turning and wrote novels.

threads.com:
Hey there anons, we've had a thread about this book a few days ago but I've made some progress and wanted to discuss it with anyone else here who has read it. Currently on chapter 18 where they've finally returned to Britain after the stint in St. Helens. A few points I wanted to touch on;
>What did you guys think about Rebekah's apparition?
I feel like a lot of the more absurd points in this book could be hand-waved away as the Revd. making shit up to entretain his family, especially if you want to take a more 'historical' point of view and try to decipher what Pynchon made up entirely from what could have reasonably happened on a more meta level, but I think discussing it thematically or taking it at face-value can be fun as well. Do you think this was a symptom of Mason's deteriorating mental health as a result of the Winds or a sign that Maskelyne was right about the Island's nature? Or better yet; do you see this as a positive thing for Mason or not? On one hand we have a lot of satanic imagery in these sections, while Mason gets more and more paranoid about the origin of his visions, describing how her tone of voice changed pitch and took on a 'beastly aspect', but on the other he was also clearly still enamored with her, and 'brought' her apparition back to England with him (By the way, do you think this was her voice guiding him by the end of the chapter before he meets the Ear?) And speaking of which;
>The Ear section and the meeting with the pretender
One of the most interesting scenes I think, from the odd entrance that Mason can not find after exiting, to him describing the experience of talking to a being that 'could only hear, never speak' as 'confessing to a desert' and finding himself being able to talk about his innermost thoughts. What did you take away from this if anything?
>Maskelyne
I think that barring our protagonists he definitely is the most intriguing figure of the book so far, especially being such a distinguished figure IRL. What did you take from his supposed meetings with Dieter? I might be ignorant of some historical fact being mentioned here, or maybe it is all fiction, but do you think this is a figure of Maskelyne's past, a legitimate apparition similar to Rebekah, or some sort of signal coming from his guilt of using his brother-in-law's influence to gain favors and step-up in life (even if he is doing it for a positive cause?) Personally, I'm leaning to the latter.
To conclude this post, I think these last five-or-so chapters after the transit of venus have been my favorite part of the book so far, and that the moment where Dixon tells Mason to tell him about Rebekah was the most personally touching moment of the entire novel. I definitely understand where some Anons are coming from when they call it comfy, plus the entire telling-a-story-in-a-storm aspect of it. Looking forward to seeing your input and finding out where the rest of this goes.

>>21271102
If you plan to teach high school, lecturing is not the way to go. Most good lesson plans follow an I-do-->we-do-->you-do model, where you model the process for something, practice it together, and set them off independently and bounce around the room from person to person keeping things on track and coaching.
Good units also scaffold skills. For instance, Most freshmen aren't even ready for concepts like symbolism and juxtaposition til the end of the year; you start them off on simple stuff like direct and indirect characterization, and being able to summarize what's happening in a text, and build from there. If you want them to learn something, you have to be willing to take it slow. It took me three years to figure this out and I'm still not perfect at it. I still struggle to work in grammar lessons.
You even have to scaffold writing. Freshmen year should be informative/narrative writing mostly, starting explanatory (analysis) really in second semester, Sophomore year is informative/explanatory, starting argument second semester, junior year is mostly explanatory/argument, moving into rhetorical analysis and more complex writing forms in the second semester, and senior year should just culminate everything.
Take a look at your place's standards for education; my school uses these, but my college classes are bound to college standards. I use these for my regular classes:
https://learning.ccsso.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/ELA_Standards1.pdf
When I teach, I have to teach standards for Reading literature, informational text, writing standards (which includes research), speaking and listening standards, and language/grammar standards. But you have to actually unpack these and determine what they mean and what skills to teach in what order.

An example unpacking would be standard RL9-10.6 - "Analyze a particular point of view or cultural experience reflected in a work of
literature from outside the United States, drawing on a wide reading of world literature"

What you need to know:
What perspective is
- what point of view is - 1st, 2nd, 3rd person POV as basics
-Point of View/Perspective as being from a Speaker, which in turn then unpacks into characterization, which in turn is unpacked into how character voice or authorial voice is created, which is through tone and diction analysis, and then diction analysis is unpacked into teaching denotation and connotation.

And that's all just 1 standard. There's a lot you have to teach in just one skill, and you can't hit them all

threads.com:
A philosophy professor standing in an auditorium filled with students asks one of them a question:
- Do you like soups?
- Yes, professor.
- So you know what soup is.
- Of course.
- Are soups good?
- Naturally, they are good.
- And is soup kisel? Can soup be milk?
- Yes.
- And you - do you think a soup is anything cooked as a stock?
- According to Wikipedia, yes.
A smile of superiority appeared on the professor's face
- Ah yes, Wikipedia!
And after a moment's thought he adds:
- I have an example for you. Let's say you have a stock of vegetables and meat. You add pants, stones and sawdust in there. Will it be a soup?
- Of course not, professor.
- So soup is something else than stock with additives!
- I think you can't put it that way.
- But why not? After all, this definition is on Wikipedia.
Faced with the student's silence, the professor goes on:
- It doesn't help, does it? My brother was a Wikipedia moderator and died of bitterness not being able to define soup.
The student is still silent, so the professor adds
- You can't give an answer, can you?
To give the student a moment to think, the professor reaches for a glass from his desk and takes a sip of borscht.
- Let's start at the beginning boy. Is milk a dish?
- Well, no... it isn't.
- And when you add cereal in there is it a dish?
Without a moment's hesitation, the student answers
- Yes.
- Then what does being a dish depend on?
The student twitches all the way:
- On the method of preparation....
- Well, that's right. So it is the addition of the cereal that makes it a dish. Now tell me more son - is there a fruit soup in the world?
- There is Mr. Professor ...
- That is, fruit soup is present in the Universe. And it is, after all, the addition of pasta that creates, by analogy with cereal, a soup, right?
- Right.
- So spaghetti with sauce is a soup? Since adding cereal to warm milk makes soup, so does adding pasta to soup! And since adding pasta to compote makes soup, according to the rules of logic, adding it to tomato sauce also makes soup.
The student is again unable to find an answer....
- And are there stews, puddings, kisiels? All these foods that appear in the world around us and resemble soups without being them?
The student answers in a trembling voice
- They do appear.
- And are they soups?
Silence has fallen in the room, so the professor repeats the question
- If not, why not?
In the absence of an answer, the professor halts his step and begins to look around the auditorium. All the students freeze.
- Tell me - the lecturer turns to the next person
- Do you believe in the only correct definition of soup, that is, by enumeration?
- No professor, I don't believe it.
The firm tone of the answer catches the professor's attention. The older man turns to the student:
- Ahh, then why don't you suggest something better?
- Soup has no definition honestly.
The professor smiles slightly while looking at the student. It promises to be a good semester.
- What do you mean to tell me young man?

Soup is a category of dishes but the word can also be used to describe something that resembles the structure of the dish but is not food, in which case it would be more accurate to describe it as "soupy" even if it can be understood when called "a soup".
There are a number of fallacies in this dialogue where the train of logic could have been interrupted.
>I have an example for you. Let's say you have a stock of vegetables and meat. You add pants, stones and sawdust in there. Will it be a soup?
>Of course not, professor.
Wrong, that is a soup. It's not soup you want to eat, but it's soupy, it's a soup.
>Then what does being a dish depend on?
The student twitches all the way:
>On the method of preparation....
Merely the method of preparation? That doesn't follow from the example given. You could prepare a bowl of cereal by putting the milk or the cereal in first, it would still be a dish either way. I would think the natural answer would include something along the lines of a dish being defined by what its ingredients are, and how they're combined, how it's served.
>That is, fruit soup is present in the Universe. And it is, after all, the addition of pasta that creates, by analogy with cereal, a soup, right?
This is incoherent.
>Right.
>So spaghetti with sauce is a soup? Since adding cereal to warm milk makes soup, so does adding pasta to soup! And since adding pasta to compote makes soup, according to the rules of logic, adding it to tomato sauce also makes soup.
Spaghetti with sauce is not a soup, it is sauce on pasta. A soup would be pasta in sauce that is liquefied to the point where the pasta is submerged and immersed. You didn't lay the requisite logical groundwork for this step for it to follow.

threads.com:
The Return of Jim and Arthur, Book the First.
ACT 1. Dashing.

When the lobsterbacks entered the building they had not at all banked on the resistance by which they were met. Their training had been sub-par; many were unmanly sorts and were relying, broadly speaking, upon the powers of terror by which a kowing citizenry was jointly trained to respond to their presence and loud voices, to immediately follow instruction to surrender and whilst grinning like apes they would manhandle as thy saw fit until further instruction had been received.

However on this occasion no sooner had they barged through the revolving doors than their first company, oft' named in quainter times The Forlorn Hope, crashed through the flooring and onto a pit of sharpened metal and lead piping in the chambers beneath. Howls of agony and the sound of bone scraping against blunted piping rang in ghast symphonies up through what seemed then like the open pits of hell.

From the floorboards climbed soldiery, not citizens but soldiery. They bore down the collapsing column of lobsterbacks who, now met with hacking and stabbing, began to attempt a retreat out upon the open streets where their numbers would fare more in their favor. Had they received more than cursory training this maneuver may have spared them some losses, whereas in panic and disarray their attempts to withdraw and regroup offered nothing but to leave the backs of their legs and necks exposed to hammer and puncture, as sharpened piping maimed them from the knees down and other, cruder, weaponry inserted itself up and around the base of their skulls and the tips of their spines.

1/2

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Many pleaded for their lives, forgetting their station and uniform, as common dogs.

More were grabbed as they tried to flee, others still were dragged by the broken legs and disjointed mangled arms and pulled back into the slaughterhouse.


Jim and Arthur were in the thick of it, not a single co-worker killed or maimed moreso than did these brothers-in-arms. By the end of the battle Arthur had begun to eat from the flesh of the riot officers; bare to the waist and his chest painted in spilled blood taken by fingertip of veteran colleagues and marked with the signs of emergent memories. Jim, for his part, stalked clad in snatched armor around and about the mouth of hell, delivering shattering blows to those either trying to escape from the pit or those half dead and dying impaled on the jutting beams.

Their efforts had been a complete victory. The entire enemy had been destroyed and their transports sat empty in streets emptier yet. More had joined as the fray had continued; thunder had sounded joined by the crackling of small arms as the enemy had rallied to its reinforcements and attempted one last desperate counter-surge before being torn to pieces.

Now all the bodies, stripped of armament, were hauled by the ton into the mouth of hell and still cries and wails came from down there as bodies crushed bodies and awakened those who had slumbered due to wounds. Just like that the New Army had gained armor superiority and even the firearms would prove yet useful; electronic shock guns that could incapacitate a quarry, large bore shotguns that would fare as company-breakers, door-breakers and mortars. Most of all value were the shields; these rectangular things that could repel bullets long enough to stave an eye-socket were of the greatest value of all.

But no mere Spartacus did either Jim, Arthur or the New Army fancy themselves; rather 'they' were Publius Licinius Crassus and 'they' were hunting down the rebel slaves, these lobsterbacks of Cavendish; these poor levies guiled to abuse the rights of Man with reckless abandon, knowing full and well the brunt of reclamation that they would suffer with their naked soft flesh in misguided attempts to insulate Cavendish for but moments until the New Army bore down upon him at each quarter and twisted foot from ankle, forearm from elbow and then tore asunder to peck clean the horish trunk.


T'was no rebellion, t'was but swift march.

"March on," sang the countrymen locked in their homes, "deliver us, deliver us, deliver us," they sang.


END OF ACT 1. Dashing.

2/2
